title-group.article-title: Time‐restricted eating did not alter insulin sensitivity or β‐cell function in adults with obesity: A randomized pilot study

aff.named-content: Division of Diabetes, Endocrinology and Metabolism, Department of Medicine
Department of Biochemistry, Molecular Biology, and Biophysics

author-notes.corresp: *Correspondence Anne E. Bantle, Division of Diabetes, Endocrinology and Metabolism, Department of Medicine, University of Minnesota, 516 Delaware Street SE, MMC 101, Minneapolis, MN 55455 USA. Email: bant0015@umn.edu

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2022 The Authors. Obesity published by Wiley Periodicals LLC on behalf of The Obesity Society.

license.license-p: This is an open access article under the terms of the http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ License, which permits use and distribution in any medium, provided the original work is properly cited, the use is non‐commercial and no modifications or adaptations are made.

sec.title: Objective
sec.p: Decreased insulin sensitivity and impairment of β‐cell function predate and predict development of type 2 diabetes mellitus. Time‐restricted eating (TRE) might have a benefit for these parameters. The objective of this pilot study was to investigate this possibility.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: Secondary analysis of a randomized controlled trial comparing 12 weeks of TRE (8‐hour eating window) to unrestricted eating (non‐TRE) was performed. Participants were adults with overweight or obesity and without diabetes. Two‐hour oral glucose tolerance testing was performed at baseline and end‐intervention. Glucose tolerance test‐derived measures of insulin sensitivity, insulin secretion, and β‐cell function were compared between groups.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Participants (17 women/3 men with mean [SD] age 45.5 [12.1] years and BMI 34.1 [7.5] kg/m2) with a prolonged eating window (15.4 [0.9] hours) were randomized to TRE (n = 11) or non‐TRE (n = 9). The quantitative insulin sensitivity check index (QUICKI), Stumvoll index, Avignon index, insulinogenic index, insulin area under the curve/glucose area under the curve, and oral disposition index did not differ between the TRE and non‐TRE groups at end‐intervention.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In adults with overweight or obesity and without diabetes, TRE did not significantly alter insulin sensitivity, insulin secretion, or β‐cell function over a 12‐week intervention. Whether TRE is beneficial in adults with prediabetes or type 2 diabetes mellitus warrants further investigation.

institution-wrap.institution: National Center for Advancing Translational Sciences
National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases

award-group.funding-source: University of Minnesota Healthy Foods, Healthy Lives Program

p.mixed-citation: BantleAE, LauKJ, WangQ, et al. Time‐restricted eating did not alter insulin sensitivity or β‐cell function in adults with obesity: A randomized pilot study. Obesity (Silver Spring). 2023;31(Suppl. 1):108‐115. doi:10.1002/oby.23620 36518093

fn.p: Funding information Larry Hillblom Foundation network grant; National Center for Advancing Translational Sciences, Grant/Award Number: UL1TR002494; National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases, Grant/Award Numbers: DK118278, DK124484, K23DK115906; National Institute on Aging, Grant/Award Number: AG065569; University of Minnesota Healthy Foods, Healthy Lives Program, Grant/Award Number: 17SFR‐2YR50LC

list-item.p: Decreased insulin sensitivity and impairment of β‐cell function are precursors of type 2 diabetes mellitus.
Previous literature has reported varying effects of time‐restricted eating on glycemic outcomes.

It is unknown whether time‐restricted eating offers benefit for insulin sensitivity, insulin secretion, or β‐cell function in participants who have overweight or obesity and are therefore at risk for developing prediabetes/diabetes.

Our pilot study did not show a difference in oral glucose tolerance test–derived measures of insulin sensitivity, insulin secretion, or β‐cell function after a 12‐week time‐restricted eating intervention when compared with control. Participants in this study had overweight or obesity, but not diabetes, at baseline.

sec.title: How might these results change the direction of research or the focus of clinical practice?

list-item.p: Time‐restricted eating may be most beneficial for improving dysglycemia in adults with preexisting prediabetes or type 2 diabetes mellitus. This warrants further investigation.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: The epidemic of obesity and overweight in the United States affects two thirds of the adult population [1] and has led to increased prevalence of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM). Insulin resistance combined with declining β‐cell function is a hallmark of prediabetes and eventual T2DM [2]; strategies to prevent these diabetes precursors have attracted intense interest. Time‐restricted eating (TRE) is an eating pattern in which food intake is restricted to a shortened interval during the day. TRE is increasingly touted as a viable weight loss method [3] based on studies in animals [4] and many [5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11], but not all [12], studies in humans. TRE offers a simplified approach to eating that makes it an attractive option for clinical use. Whether this eating strategy is effective for T2DM prevention remains unknown.

Promising effects of TRE on glycemic measures have been reported. Most studies reporting positive effects have been small, short term (<6 weeks), and performed in men [13, 14, 15, 16]. In men with obesity and elevated fasting glucose (n = 15), 7 days of TRE (9‐hour eating window) improved glycemic response to a test meal compared with baseline [13]. In a randomized crossover study in men with overweight or obesity (n = 11), 5 days of isoenergetic TRE (8‐hour eating window) reduced nocturnal glucose concentration and postprandial glycemic response to a breakfast meal, compared with an extended daily feeding window (15 hours) [16]. In a randomized crossover study of early TRE over 5 weeks (6‐hour eating window, completion of meals before 3 p.m.) in men with prediabetes (n = 8), the TRE intervention improved insulin sensitivity and β‐cell responsiveness measured by the insulinogenic index compared with a 12‐hour eating window [14]. Early TRE (6‐hour eating window, completion of meals by 2 p.m.) also decreased mean 24‐hour glucose and glycemic excursions compared with control in a 4‐day randomized crossover study in adults with overweight (n = 11) [15].

Studies of TRE combined with caloric restriction showed variable effects on glycemia. A recent large (n = 139) randomized trial of TRE with caloric restriction in participants with obesity reported decreased 2‐hour postprandial glucose and decreased homeostatic model assessment of insulin resistance (HOMA‐IR) after 12 months of TRE (8‐hour eating window, ending at 4 p.m.) compared with baseline, but with no difference in comparison with a time‐unrestricted caloric restriction group [17]. There was also no difference in either group at 12 months in the insulin disposition index [17]. In a randomized trial of TRE combined with a commercial weight loss program including 78 participants with obesity, improvement in fasting glucose was reported after 8 weeks of TRE compared with baseline, with the largest reductions in participants with elevated fasting glucose at baseline [11].

To better understand the effect of TRE on insulin sensitivity, insulin secretion, and β‐cell function in participants at risk for T2DM, we performed a secondary analysis of our previously published randomized clinical trial of TRE with an 8‐hour eating window in human participants without diabetes [8]. Static and dynamic indices derived from oral glucose tolerance testing (OGTT) were used to examine the effects of TRE relative to unrestricted eating (non‐TRE). We hypothesized that OGTT‐derived measures of insulin sensitivity, insulin secretion, and β‐cell function would improve following 12 weeks of TRE, as compared with baseline and as compared with the non‐TRE control intervention.

sec.title: Study design
sec.p: This study is a secondary analysis of a previously published randomized controlled trial comparing 12 weeks of TRE (8‐hour window) to non‐TRE in 20 adults with obesity [8]. The purpose of our analysis was to examine the effect of TRE on β‐cell function, as determined by OGTT. This study was registered on ClinicalTrials.gov (NCT 03129581). All study procedures were approved by the University of Minnesota and the Salk Institute Institutional Review Boards, and participants provided written informed consent before beginning study procedures.

sec.title: Eligibility criteria
sec.p: As previously published [8], women and men aged 18 to 65 years with BMI ≥ 25 kg/m2 were recruited. Participants were eligible to enroll in the trial if they met the following criteria: had a stable work and sleep schedule (awake/sleep within a 2‐hour time frame 6 of 7 days, with variance ≤ 4 hours on the seventh day), owned a smartphone compatible with the myCircadianClock mobile application (Salk Institute, La Jolla, California, www.mycircadianclock.org), had a usual daily eating window ≥ 14 h/d, demonstrated ability to consistently log eating occasions (≥ 2 eating events ≥ 5 hours apart per day >1 d/wk), were not pregnant or planning to become pregnant, and were free of chronic disease. Participants were excluded if pre‐intervention fasting glucose, 2‐hour OGTT result, or hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) was consistent with a diagnosis of diabetes.

sec.title: Intervention
sec.p: Enrolled participants were randomly assigned to TRE or non‐TRE (control), stratified by sex (male or female), and age (< 45 years or ≥ 45 years old). Participants in the TRE group were instructed to adhere to a self‐selected daily 8‐hour eating window, with ad libitum food intake. Participants in the non‐TRE group were instructed to continue their usual eating habits. No additional dietary education was provided to either group. The intervention lasted 12 weeks. Participants were required to log dietary intake using the myCircadianClock mobile application throughout the study period. Participants received weekly feedback from the study team (text, email, phone call) regarding compliance with their eating window (TRE group) and logging adherence (both groups).

sec.title: Data collection
sec.p: Participants completed a 75‐g, 2‐hour OGTT at baseline and at the end of 12 weeks of the assigned diet intervention. The OGTT was performed with start time between 8 a.m. and 12 p.m., following a fast of at least 8 hours. After consumption of 75 g of oral glucose, plasma glucose and serum insulin levels were sampled every 30 minutes for 2 hours. Plasma glucose was measured using a modified hexokinase method on the Dimension Vista 1500, and serum insulin was measured using a two‐site chemiluminescent sandwich immunoassay on the Advia Centaur (Siemens Healthineers). Analyses were completed by the University of Minnesota Acute Care Laboratory.

The OGTT was chosen rather than a mixed meal tolerance test, insulin clamp procedure, or other measurement technique to maximize reproducibility and to minimize burden to study participants and staff. Although a mixed meal tolerance test may provide a more physiologically relevant stimulus as compared with OGTT, results are more variable [18], and we did not have access to a metabolic kitchen for appropriate meal preparation. Continuous glucose monitoring data were collected during the study, and results have been previously published [8].
Study data were collected and managed using the REDCap electronic data capture tools hosted at the University of Minnesota [19, 20].

sec.title: OGTT‐derived indices of insulin secretion, insulin sensitivity, and β‐cell function
sec.p: OGTT data were used to calculate measures of β‐cell function, insulin secretion, and insulin sensitivity. Results for HOMA‐IR and the Matsuda index have been previously published [8]. Details for each included index are given next. A guide to interpretation of the results for each index is provided in Supporting Information Table S1.

Both static and dynamic indices were used in these analyses. Static indices, such as the quantitative insulin sensitivity check index (QUICKI) [21], are derived from fasting insulin and glucose levels. Dynamic indices, such as the Avignon index [22], Stumvoll index [23, 24], or insulinogenic index [25], require performing an OGTT to measure glucose and insulin levels at specific time points. Studies have suggested that dynamic measures of insulin resistance are stronger predictors of future prediabetes or diabetes [26] and that they correlate better with hyperinsulinemic euglycemic clamp results [27]. Although insulin clamp studies are considered the gold standard for assessing insulin sensitivity and β‐cell function, they are labor‐intensive and costly to perform [28], and they were not included in the clinical trial [8].

sec.title: QUICKI index
sec.p: The QUICKI is similar to the HOMA‐IR equation, but unlike HOMA‐IR, it transforms the data by taking the logarithm and reciprocal of fasting glucose and insulin [21]. It has been extensively validated as a measure of insulin sensitivity [29, 30]. Formula:1/logI0+logG0
G0, fasting glucose (mg/dL); I0, fasting insulin (μIU/mL).

sec.title: Stumvoll index
sec.p: Both the Avignon index and the Stumvoll index incorporate demographic data, with correlation coefficients relative to the hyperinsulinemic euglycemic clamp that are comparable, if not better than, the Matsuda index [31].

The Stumvoll index is a measure of insulin sensitivity and insulin release [23]. Stumvoll index equations were generated using multiple linear regression analysis, adapted to the availabilities of sampling times during OGTT, and incorporated demographic data such as age, sex, and BMI [23, 31, 32]. The Stumvoll index was calculated two ways for this study.
Formula Method 1 (with demographic data):0.222–0.00333×BMI−0.0000779×I120–0.000422×Age
I120, insulin at 120 minutes (pmol/L).
Formula Method 2 (without demographic data):0.156–0.0000459×I120–0.000321×I0–0.00541×G120
I120, insulin at 120 minutes (pmol/L); I0, fasting insulin (pmol/L); G120, glucose at 120 minutes (mmol/L).

sec.title: Avignon index
sec.p: The Avignon index uses plasma insulin, plasma glucose, and apparent glucose distribution volume in the basal state (Sib) and at the second hour of OGTT (Si2h). The average of Sib and Si2h is then used to calculate Sim [22]. Using this method, both glucose tolerance and insulin sensitivity can be estimated [31].
Formula:Sib=108/I0×G0×VD
I0, fasting insulin (μIU/mL); G0, fasting glucose (mg/dL).Si2h=108/I120h×G120h×VD
I120, insulin at 120 minutes (μIU/mL); G120 = glucose at 120 minutes (mg/dL).Sim=0.137xSib+Si2h/2
VD is an estimate of the apparent glucose distribution volume, which is calculated as 150 mL × body weight in kg [22].

sec.title: Insulinogenic index
sec.p: The insulinogenic index is an index of insulin secretion, which is used to measure early phase insulin response to a glucose challenge [25, 33].Formula:100I30−I0/G30−G0
I0, fasting insulin (μIU/mL); G0, fasting glucose (mg/dL); I30, insulin at 30 minutes (μIU/mL); G30, glucose at 30 minutes (mg/dL).

sec.title: Area under the insulin curve/area under the glucose curve
sec.p: Late‐phase insulin secretion can be assessed using the ratio of area under the insulin curve to area under the glucose curve from 60 to 120 minutes [34]. The trapezoidal method was used to calculate glucose area under the curve (AUC) and insulin AUC during OGTT.Formula:IAUC60–120/GAUC60–120
IAUC60–120, insulin AUC (μIU/mL) from 60 to 120 minutes; GAUC 60–120, glucose AUC (mg/dL) from 60 to 120 minutes.

sec.title: Oral disposition index
sec.p: The oral disposition index uses OGTT data to measure β‐cell function adjusted for insulin sensitivity. It has been shown to be predictive of future T2DM risk [35]. A hyperbolic relationship between insulin sensitivity (1/I0) and early insulin response ((I30 − I0)/(G30 − G0)) in our data was confirmed prior to calculation of the oral disposition index; additional detail can be found in Supporting Information Table S2.Formula:ΔI0–30/ΔG0–30×1/I0
ΔI0–3, change in insulin levels (μIU/mL) between fasting and at 30 minutes; ΔG0–30, change in glucose levels (mg/dL) between fasting and at 30 minutes; I0, fasting insulin (μIU/mL).

sec.title: Statistical analyses
sec.p: Descriptive statistics were calculated and are presented by groups. Paired t tests were used to evaluate pre/post change within each group. Two‐sample t tests were performed to compare pre/post change between groups. Correlation analyses were conducted to examine the association between changes in eating window and changes in glucose/insulin indices. P values < 0.05 were considered statistically significant. No adjustments were made for multiple comparisons. Statistical analyses were performed in SAS software, version 9.4 (SAS Institute Inc., Cary, North Carolina).

sec.title: RESULTS
sec.p: Twenty women and men with overweight or obesity were included in this study. Baseline characteristics of the participants are shown in Table 1. As previously reported, participants did not have diabetes at baseline [8]. The TRE group, but not the non‐TRE group, had mean 2‐hour OGTT glucose suggestive of prediabetes at baseline (Table 1) [8].

fn.p: Note: Data are shown as mean (SD) or n. Data were previously published [8] and are recapitulated here.
Abbreviations: HbA1c, hemoglobin A1c; OGTT, oral glucose tolerance testing; TRE, time‐restricted eating.
Significantly different between TRE and non‐TRE groups at baseline (p < 0.05).

sec.p: As previously reported, the eating window in the TRE group significantly declined compared with baseline (−5.4 [SD 2.2] hours; p < 0.01), and the non‐TRE group eating window did not change [8]. Participants randomized to the TRE group lost weight during the study intervention, which was significant relative to baseline (−3.7% [SD 1.8%], p < 0.01) and relative to the non‐TRE control group (p = 0.04) [8].

The length of fast prior to collection of the OGTT was required to be > 8 hours but was not standardized in the study protocol. There was no significant difference between groups in fasting duration prior to the OGTT at baseline (mean ± SD: 824.4 ± 124.4 minutes for the TRE group; 759.6 ± 70.4 minutes for the non‐TRE group, p = 0.09) or at end‐intervention (917.6 ± 89.8 minutes for the TRE group; 805.4 ± 155.6 minutes for the non‐TRE group, p = 0.10).

TRE was not associated with any change in HOMA‐IR or the Matsuda index, as reported in the original publication [8]. In this study, we additionally found that 12 weeks of TRE did not significantly alter any OGTT‐based measure of insulin sensitivity (QUICKI index, Stumvoll index, and Avignon index) relative to the non‐TRE group (Table 2). There was a statistically significant improvement in the Avignon index Si2h and Sim in the TRE group at 12 weeks compared with baseline, and this difference was not seen in the non‐TRE group. There was no difference in the OGTT‐derived indices of insulin secretion or β‐cell function (insulinogenic index, insulin AUC/glucose AUC, or the oral disposition index) relative to baseline or to the non‐TRE group.

caption.p: Comparison of pre‐ and post‐intervention OGTT measures

tr.th: Comparison of pre/post change between TRE and non‐TRE

fn.p: Note: p < 0.05 are shown in bold.

Abbreviations: AUC, area under the curve; HbA1c, hemoglobin A1c; OGTT, oral glucose tolerance testing; QUICKI, quantitative insulin sensitivity check index; Si2h, Avignon index at 2nd hour of OGTT; Sib, Avignon index in basal state; Sim, average of Sib and Si2h; TRE, time‐restricted eating.

n varies from 8 to 11 across different indices; three participants (two TRE and one non‐TRE) had missing values for insulin or glucose from some but not all time points during the OGTT. Data were used when available.

sec.p: The original publication reported a correlation between the degree of eating window restriction with fat mass loss (r = 0.60; p = 0.05) and visceral fat loss (r = 0.72; p = 0.01) [8]. However, we did not identify any correlation between the degree of eating window restriction and any observed changes in OGTT‐derived measures in the new analyses (Table 3).

caption.p: Correlation between change in eating window and change in OGTT‐derived indices over the 12‐week intervention

fn.p: Abbreviations: HOMA‐IR, homeostatic model assessment of insulin resistance; OGTT, oral glucose tolerance testing; QUICKI, quantitative insulin sensitivity check index; Sim, average of Sib and Si2h; TRE, time‐restricted eating.

Three participants (two TRE and one non‐TRE) had missing values for insulin or glucose from some but not all time points during the OGTT. Data were used when available for calculation of OGTT indices.

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: In this exploratory study, we examined the effect of TRE on OGTT‐derived measures of insulin secretion, insulin sensitivity, and β‐cell function during a 12‐week randomized controlled trial of TRE in participants with overweight or obesity and without T2DM. Previous literature has reported mixed results of TRE on glycemic measures in human participants [12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17]. We found that 12 weeks of TRE with an 8‐hour eating window did not alter multiple OGTT‐derived measures when compared with a non‐TRE intervention in participants who did not have T2DM.

Ad libitum TRE, in which participants are allowed unlimited intake, is generally associated with weight loss [5, 6, 7, 8, 10]. Given that weight loss can prevent and delay progression to T2DM [36, 37], or reverse T2DM [38], there has been interest in TRE as a method to improve glycemic measures. Several small studies have supported this hypothesis [13, 14, 15, 16]. In particular, in participants with prediabetes and thus, high risk of progression to T2DM, TRE improved insulin sensitivity and insulin secretion as measured by the insulinogenic index [14]. However, larger trials have not shown similar improvements. In a recent randomized controlled trial of TRE with an 8‐hour eating window done in 116 participants with overweight/obesity and without diabetes, Lowe et al. found no significant difference in static glycemic measures including HOMA‐IR, HbA1c, fasting glucose, and fasting insulin [12]. Likewise, Liu et al. recently reported a randomized controlled trial comparing 12 months of TRE with caloric restriction (8‐hour eating window) to caloric restriction alone in 139 participants with obesity and without diabetes and found no difference in HOMA‐IR, 2‐hour postprandial glucose, or the insulin disposition index between TRE and control [17]. There was improvement in 2‐hour postprandial glucose and HOMA‐IR in the TRE with caloric restriction group at 12 months, when compared with baseline [17]. These changes occurred in the setting of caloric restriction and weight loss greater than that seen in our trial and may have been driven by these differences rather than TRE alone. Similar to our study, the Lowe et al. and Liu et al. trials enrolled participants without diabetes but with other risk factors for T2DM, including overweight or obesity. If there is an effect of TRE on insulin sensitivity or β‐cell function, as suggested by small trials, it is plausible that this will only be seen in those with highest risk (i.e., participants who have already developed prediabetes or T2DM).

Our study has several strengths. We conducted a secondary analysis of a randomized controlled trial that included measurement of OGTT at baseline and following a 12‐week intervention. The inclusion of OGTT data allowed assessment of insulin sensitivity, insulin secretion, and β‐cell function before and after TRE and comparison to an appropriate control intervention. A reduction in the eating window was demonstrated for participants assigned to TRE, thus providing a robust sample for our analysis [8].

Several limitations also exist. The small sample size and wider variability of OGTT testing, as compared with hyperinsulinemic euglycemic insulin clamp, may mean that an effect of TRE was missed. In addition, although the participants in this trial had overweight or obesity and thus future risk of T2DM, they did not have significant dysglycemia at baseline. This decreases any possible effect size and may have limited our ability to detect a difference, even if present. We were unable to assess any effect of total caloric intake or macronutrient composition on the outcomes because food volume was not quantified, an acknowledged limitation. In addition, our pilot study involved primarily White female participants, and caution should be exercised generalizing to other populations. Last, we acknowledge that we could not assess the effect of TRE timing (early versus late in the day eating) on outcomes, because participants were allowed to self‐select their eating window to facilitate compliance. Most participants in the TRE arm of the trial self‐selected an 8‐hour eating window starting in the late morning (10:40 a.m.) and ending in the early evening (6:40 p.m.) [8]. It is possible that early TRE, in which meals are limited to the morning and early afternoon, may have greater metabolic benefit as compared with TRE with an eating window later in the day [14, 15]. Self‐selection of the eating window in this study also meant that the fast prior to the OGTT was not standardized. Although we did not observe any significant difference in the fasting duration between groups at either the baseline OGTT or end‐intervention OGTT, there was a trend toward a longer fasting duration in the TRE group compared with the non‐TRE group (p = 0.10). Whether habituation of the individual to their eating window and the discrepancy between the end of the eating window and OGTT initiation may affect OGTT results remains unknown; this is an acknowledged limitation for which larger and longer studies are warranted.

sec.title: CONCLUSION
sec.p: In adults with overweight or obesity and without diabetes, this pilot study demonstrated that a 12‐week TRE intervention with an 8‐hour eating window did not significantly alter insulin sensitivity, insulin secretion, or β‐cell function. Whether TRE may be beneficial in adults with prediabetes or T2DM warrants further investigation.

sec.title: AUTHOR CONTRIBUTIONS
sec.p: Lisa S. Chow and Douglas G. Mashek designed the research; Lisa S. Chow, Kheng Joe Lau, Qi Wang, and Emily N. C. Manoogian conducted the research; Kheng Joe Lau, Qi Wang, and Lisa S. Chow analyzed data; Anne E. Bantle, Kheng Joe Lau, and Lisa S. Chow wrote this manuscript. All authors edited the manuscript and provided intellectual input. Lisa S. Chow has primary responsibility for the final content; all authors read and approved of the final manuscript.

sec.title: CONFLICT OF INTEREST
sec.p: SP has authored the books The Circadian Code and The Circadian Diabetes Code, for which he receives author royalties and in which he specifically recommends TRE. The other authors declared no conflict of interest.

Table S2. Demonstration of hyperbolic relationship for oral disposition index calculation.

ln(∆I 0–30/∆G 0–30 or incAUCins/glu) was estimated as a linear function of ln(1/fasting insulin) using regression analysis. A hyperbolic relationship was presumed if the 95% confidence interval (CI) of the slope included −1.
